titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Steichen Family Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 16, 2019 at 03:13

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Steichen family papers consist of photographs, correspondence, writings, exhibition materials, legal papers, genealogical materials, audiovisual materials, digital media, and other papers relating to Edward J. Steichen and members of his family, including his wives Clara Smith Steichen, Dana Steichen, and Joanna T. Steichen, his daughters Mary Steichen Calderone and Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen, his granddaughters Linda and Nell Martin and Francesca and Maria Calderone-Steichen, and his sister Lilian "Paula" Steichen and her husband, poet Carl Sandburg. Photographs and photograph albums by Edward Steichen and other photographers include portraits of Edward Steichen and other family members, photographs of family homes, and other subjects. Correspondence includes family correspondence with Carl Sandburg, and correspondence with playwright Edward Albee and others. Writings include works by family members, including Joanna T. Steichen and Francesca Steichen Calderone, as well as writings of others about Edward Steichen and Mary Calderone Steichen. Exhibition materials document exhibitions created by or relating to Edward Steichen. Legal papers include both estate papers and documentation of a lawsuit with the Museum of Modern Art regarding the disputed ownership of ''Vue de Collioure a l'Eglise,'' a painting by Matisse lent by Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen and the subsequent sale of the painting by the Steichen family. Audiovisual materials include oral histories and documentaries about Edward Steichen.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three groupings: February 2014 Acquisition; 5 June 2014 Acquisition; and 25 June 2014 Acquisition.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 26, 27 (audiovisual materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 28, 39 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Steichen Family Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Steichen Family Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

Materials from the collections may be added to the Beinecke Digital Library as low-resolution files restricted to Yale-only access. In 2030, low-resolution images from the collections in the digital library may be made available to all library users accessing the digital library via the internet.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Edward J. Steichen
bioghist.p: Edward J. Steichen (1879-1973) was a photographer and painter, as well as an art gallery and museum curator. Born in Luxembourg, he emigrated to the United States in 1881. Steichen was married three times. His first marriage, to Clara Smith Steichen (1875-1952), ended in divorce in 1922. His second marriage, to Dana Steichen, spanned from 1923 to her death in 1957. Steichen's third marriage, to Joanna T. Steichen, began in 1960 and lasted until his death.

bioghist.head: Mary Steichen Calderone
bioghist.p: Mary Steichen Calderone (1904-1998), daughter of photographer and artist Edward J. Steichen and Clara Smith Steichen, was a physician and a public health advocate for sex education. She had four daughters: Linda Martin and Nell Martin with her first husband, W. Lon Martin, and Francesca Calderone-Steichen and Maria Calderone-Steichen with her second husband, Frank Calderone.

bioghist.head: Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen
bioghist.p: Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen (1908-1988), daughter of photographer and artist Edward J. Steichen and Clara Smith Steichen, was an administrative assistant from 1950 to 1960 to the editor in chief at the Doubleday Publishing Company, Kenneth Dale McCormick.

bioghist.head: Lilian "Paula" Steichen
bioghist.p: Lilian "Paula" Steichen (1883-1977) was the sister of photographer and artist Edward J. Steichen and wife of poet Carl Sandburg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Steichen family papers consist of photographs, correspondence, writings, exhibition materials, legal papers, genealogical materials, audiovisual materials, digital media, and other papers relating to Edward J. Steichen and members of his family, including his wives Clara Smith Steichen, Dana Steichen, and Joanna T. Steichen, his daughters Mary Steichen Calderone and Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen, his granddaughters Linda and Nell Martin and Francesca and Maria Calderone-Steichen, and his sister Lilian "Paula" Steichen and her husband, poet Carl Sandburg. Photographs and photograph albums by Edward Steichen and other photographers include portraits of Edward Steichen and other family members, photographs of family homes, and other subjects. Correspondence includes family correspondence with Carl Sandburg, and correspondence with playwright Edward Albee and others. Writings include works by family members, including Joanna T. Steichen and Francesca Steichen-Calderone, as well as writings of others about Edward Steichen and Mary Calderone Steichen. Exhibition materials document exhibitions created by or relating to Edward Steichen. Legal papers include both estate papers and documentation of a lawsuit with the Museum of Modern Art regarding the disputed ownership of ''Vue de Collioure a l'Eglise,'' a painting by Matisse lent by Charlotte "Kate" Rodina Steichen and the subsequent sale of the painting by the Steichen family. Audiovisual materials include oral histories and documentaries about Edward Steichen.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in roughly the order in which the materials were received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes one snapshot of Mary Steichen Calderone, her father, aunt, and uncle in the snow, Christmas Day 1914; two photographs taken at Voulangis, one including the elderly Edward Steichen; and one negative of Mary Steichen Calderone in 1938 when she was Mary Steichen Martin, and her daughter Lydia by her first husband.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various magazines, journals and brochures related to Edward Steichen and his work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A green album of photographs of Edward J. Steichen, compiled by his third wife, Joanna Tuab Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes the following:
"Old Legal Documents: passports etc." for Edward Steichen
Certificate of completion of courses in elementary school and subsequent eligibility for high school, Public Schools of Milwaukee, July 3, 1894 [6th District School]
Certificate of Naturalization, Milwaukee County, USA, March 27, 1900. Signed Eduard J.

Passport: March 29, 1900 [signed Eduard J. Steichen]. Large parchment sheet, good for two years. Description: Age 21; Height 5 feet 11 1/2 inches; high forehead; blue eyes; Roman nose; normal mouth; round chin; brown hair; Fair complexion; round, full face.

Passport: March 13, 1920 [signed Edward J. Steichen] Description: Age 40 years; height 6 feet 1 inch; forehead broad; eyes blue gray; Hair straight; mouth straight; chin round; hair dark; complexion: medium; face oval; distinguishing marks: birth mark over eye; date of birth: March 27, 2879; occupation: artist. #185281.
Xeroxed copy, Notice of Separation from the US Naval Service, Feb 26, 1942

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Edward Steichen - Clara Smith Steichen French divorce papers, carbon copy, and related correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence to and from Edward Steichen, including one handwritten letter from his mother, Marie Kemp Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes exhibition information and photographs from "Within the Family: Private and Professional Photography by Edward Steichen," March 6-April 17, 1994, The Gallery at Briston-Myers Squibb, Princeton, NJ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a bound text: "Edward J. Steichen: A Documentary" by Claude Waringo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a Travelers Aid Society public service brochure: "Help Me Find My Boy!" with photographs by Edward Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Magazines, Journals, Clippings, Brochures and Programs featuring Edward Steichen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes magazines, journals, clippings, brochures, and programs featuring Edward Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes magazines, journals, clippings, brochures, and programs featuring Edward Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes records regarding the disposition of Steichen's property in Redding, CT.

Transcripts of Joanna Steichen on Edward Steichen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Grace Mayer's chronology. Grace Mayer was Steichen's assistant at the Museum of Modern Art for many years.

"The First Picture Book: Everyday Things for Babies"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inlcudes Mary Steichen Calderone's file on Edward Steichen's Hecksher Museum exhibition, including a list of Steichen paintings she loaned to the museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes "From Then Till Now," by James Barnes, an account of WWI involving Edward Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of Voulangis, France [Mary Steichen Calderone's childhood home in the French countryside].

did.unittitle: Testimony to International Organizations Employees Loyalty Board

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a torn black binder with poems by others. Inscribed on inside cover, "Mary Steichen Martin, Harmon, NY, Valuable, reward if returned to owner."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yellow folder entitled "Book" containing excerpts by Francesca Calderone-Steichen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a white notebook, "Let us Celebrate Her Life," Memorial Tribute to Mary Steichen Calderone, October 27, 1999.
